definitions.definition: a hard black mineral that is found below the ground and burnt to produce heat

examples.text: I put more coal on the fire.
She sat by the coal fire in the kitchen.
Plans were being drawn up for the privatization of the coal industry.
These men had spent their lives breathing coal dust.
There are substantial reserves of methane gas trapped in coal seams in the area.
Put some more coal on the fire.

definitions.definition: a piece of coal, especially one that is burning

examples.text: A hot coal fell out of the fire and burnt the carpet.
Red-hot coals glowed in the fireplace.

definitions.definition: to take goods to a place where there are already plenty of them; to supply something where it is not needed
to criticize somebody severely because they have done something wrong

examples.text: I was hauled over the coals by my boss for being late.

wordOrigin: Old English col (in the senses ‘glowing ember’ and ‘charred remnant’), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch kool and German Kohle. The sense ‘combustible mineral used as fuel’ dates from Middle English.
